record.translation[0].definitions[0].def: information about something that is written down or stored on computer, film etc so that it can be looked at in the future
record.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: According to official records, five people were killed last year near that road junction.
I try to keep a record of everything I spend.
record.translation[0].definitions[1].def: the fastest speed, longest distance, highest or lowest level etc that has ever been achieved or reached, especially in sport
record.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The American team set a new world record in the sprint relay.
record.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a round flat piece of plastic with a hole in the middle that music and sound are stored on
record.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: I spent a lot of time listening to records.
My dad’s got a huge record collection.
record.translation[0].definitions[3].def: the facts about how successful, good, bad etc someone or something has been in the past
record.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: the company’s track record in improving conditions
Chemistry graduates have a good record in finding employment.
Mr Davis defended the government’s record on unemployment  (=what they have done about unemployment).
record.translation[0].definitions[4].def: information kept by the police that shows someone has committed a crime
record.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: He’s only 18 and he already has a record.
They won’t employ anyone with a criminal record.
record.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 1: information about something that is written down or stored on computer, film etc so that it can be looked at in the future
record.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: the records show something
Official records show that 44 businesses have stopped trading in the last 12 months.
keep a record
Teachers keep a record of students’ progress.
maintain a record
The directors are responsible for maintaining adequate accounting records.
place/put something on record
I wish to put on record my objection to the scheme.
access records
Every citizen has the right to access their medical records.
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + record
a written record
Where written records do survive, they are incomplete.
historical records
Using historical records, we have produced an image of the temple.
official records
This has been the wettest winter since official records began.
an accurate record
Many hospitals did not keep accurate records.
a detailed record
Edwardian travellers left detailed records of their journeys.
a proper record
Failure to maintain proper records would be a criminal offence.
confidential records
They were transferring confidential student records onto computer.
a permanent record
You will have a permanent record of your work.
medical/hospital/health etc records
The hospital could not find my mother’s medical records.
Patients’ hospital records are kept on a database.
financial records
The company’s financial records must be up-to-date.
public records
He found the information while examining public records.
police records
Violent assaults rose 39 percent, according to police records.
the biggest/highest etc on record
Last summer was one of the hottest on record.
a matter of public record
His salary is a matter of public record.
record.translation[0].note_box[1].headin: – Meaning 2: the fastest speed, longest distance, highest or lowest level etc that has ever been achieved or reached, especially in sport
record.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: He broke the world record twice.
She smashed the record by a massive 28 seconds.
Davies holds the record for most points in a season.
The twenty-year-old set a new British record of 44.47 secs.
Woods equalled the course record and finished eleven under par.
Davis tied a team record by hitting six field goals.
Another record will fall on the last day of the season, if Arsenal win their final game.
The price of oil has hit an all-time record.
Powell equalled the 100 metres world record with a time of 9.77 seconds.
He won a gold medal and broke the Olympic record by 44 records.
Jones won in 10.93 seconds, a new British record.
Lewis set the fastest lap with a new track record.
Irvin holds a team record with 111 catches this season.
Pollution in the lake has reached record levels.
The stock market reached a record high on August 21.
They will make another record attempt next year.
record.translation[0].note_box[2].sectio: record
information about something that is written down
your medical records
the public records office
I have to keep a record of all my spending when I’m travelling on business.
file
a set of written records, or information stored on a computer under a particular name
He began reading the file on the case.
I think I may have accidentally deleted the file.
accounts
an exact record of the money that a company has received and spent
Companies are required by law to publish their annual accounts.
Someone had been falsifying the accounts.
The company’s books all seemed to be in order.
ledger
one of the official books in which a company’s financial records are kept, which show how much it has received and spent
The costs have been moved from one column of the ledger to another.
minutes
an official written record of what is said and decided at a meeting
Both points are mentioned in the minutes of the last meeting on August 3rd.
diary
a book in which you regularly write down the things that have happened to you
In his diary he wrote, ‘It s lovely having him here, we’ve had so many cosy talks.’
I’ll just check in my diary to see if I’m free.
blog
a web page on the Internet on which someone regularly writes about their life, opinions, or a particular subject
I may not always agree with David, but I always read his blog.
register
an official list of names of people, organizations etc
Guests must sign the hotel register.
the national register of births, deaths, and marriages
Lloyds Register of Shipping
roll
an official list of names, especially of people who are allowed to do something such as vote or be in a class at school
the electoral roll  (=list of people who can vote in an area)
The teacher called the roll  (=read out the list of the names of the students, who then have to say if they are present).
log
an official record that is kept on a ship or plane
Mr Appleby said he complained to a senior officer, who made a note in the ship’s log.
record.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to write information down or store it in a computer or on film so that it can be looked at in the future
record.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Her husband made her record every penny she spent.
The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death.
He recorded that the operation was successful.
In 1892 it is recorded that the weather became so cold that the river froze over.
record.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to store music, sound, television programmes etc on a disc or tape so that people can listen to them or watch them again
record.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The group has just recorded a new album.
I’ll record the film and we can all watch it later.
record.translation[1].definitions[2].def: if an instrument records the size, speed, temperature etc of something, it measures it and keeps that information
record.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Wind speeds of up to 100 mph have been recorded.
record.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a piece of information that is written down or stored on computer, film etc so that it can be looked at in the future
record.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: The exchange checked its employment records but found no trace of the individual involved.
There’s no record of what was said at their private meetings.
record.translation[2].definitions[1].def: written down or stored in a record
record.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: The Italian market had one of its most depressing years on record  (=that has ever been recorded).
record.translation[2].definitions[2].def: the best or highest level that has ever been reached
record.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: The price surpassed the previous record of $165,000 for one of his paintings.
record.translation[2].definitions[3].def: the known facts about the past behaviour and success of a person or company
record.translation[2].definitions[3].exa: The company had a solid record of sales growth for several years.
He has an impressive track record (=record).
He strongly defended his record as chief executive.
record.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: Corporations issued a record $200 billion in bonds.
record.translation[4].definitions[0].def: to write information down or store it in a computer etc so that it can be looked at in the future
record.translation[4].definitions[0].exa: We record the amount of time that people have off work because of sickness.
record.translation[4].definitions[1].def: if a company, share etc records gains, losses etc of a particular amount, it makes those gains, losses etc
record.translation[4].definitions[1].exa: Shares recorded sharp gains as market worries lessened.
